title: Friday, 3rd February, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

HI there

PM11:01am

We've had a publishing problem overnight -- and was expecting that to continue

PM11:01am

But it hasn't shock

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Just had an email saying today is National Sickie Day

PM11:02am

Now they tell us.

PM11:02am

You need to plan Sickies

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Ann Francke, Chief Executive of the CMI, said: “So-called “National Sickie Day” – apparently the worst day of the year for worker absenteeism – may sound like a frivolous PR story, but it should serve as a reminder to employers of the importance of tackling stress and unhappiness in the workplace. Our recent research highlighted the fact that the average manager in the UK works an extra 29 days over the course of a year, with over half of managers saying their working hours have a negative impact on their stress levels. All of which could have a disastrous impact on the nation’s productivity, as well as the personal wellbeing of staff.

The reality is we all have a role to play in improving the wellbeing of the UK’s workforce. Championing inclusive working cultures will have a positive impact on the workplace, as well as tackling the ‘always on’ culture of constantly checking emails on smartphones and tablets out of office hours.

PM11:03am

We do need to tackle stress and unhappiness in the workplace.

PM11:04am

11:04 am

PM11:04am

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Is this down to China Bryce?

BE11:05am

Yeah, pretty much.

PM11:05am

Was just reading Cap economics on this repo move

11:05 am
PM11:05am

It's interesing

PM11:05am

And educational

PM11:05am

he People’s Bank has raised the interest rate that it charges when providing funds in China’s repo market. This is the clearest evidence so far that monetary policy is being tightened and that supporting growth is no longer the primary immediate goal of China’s policymakers.
 Effective today, the People’s Bank has raised the rates on the reverse repo operations it conducts with banks by 10 basis points. (See Chart 1.) The hikes are small and may not have much of an immediate effect on interbank repo rates which were already trading well above the rate offered by the PBOC.

11:05 am
PM11:06am

nstead, the move is best seen as an official acknowledgement of the on-the-ground tightening that has been evident since November: the PBOC had previously been pushing interbank rates up by adjusting the quantity (rather than the price) of the funds it provides. In late January, the PBOC also increased the rate offered on its Medium-term Lending Facility (MLF). Nonetheless, the repo rate hikes provide the clearest confirmation yet of a shift toward policy tightening.

PM11:06am

Repo rates are arguably more useful guides to the policy stance than the more closely-watched benchmark rates. Indeed, in our view, the 7-day PBOC reverse repo now functions as China’s de-facto policy rate. (See our Focus, “A primer on China’s new monetary policy regime”, 10th October 2016.)
 After all, the repo market is now the primary channel through which the PBOC manages monetary conditions. Last year alone, the PBOC injected a gross RMB25trn via reverse repos, partly to offset liquidity withdrawals from foreign exchange sales. In contrast, gross injections via MLF, its next biggest channel for regular liquidity provision, totalled a mere RMB4.3trn.
 The growing importance of interbank rates reflects the diminished effectiveness of the traditional reserve requirement and benchmark rate tools in setting monetary conditions as credit markets have diversified.

PM11:06am

So the repo rate is China's de facto policy rate

11:06 am
PM11:06am

That's something to remember

PM11:07am

Looking to rein in credit growth

PM11:07am

Julian Evans-Pritchard the economist there

PM11:07am

PM11:14am

WASHINGTON—President Donald Trump on Friday plans to sign an executive action to scale back the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial-overhaul law, in a sweeping plan to dismantle much of the regulatory system put in place after the financial crisis.

Mr. Trump also plans another executive action aimed at rolling back a controversial regulation scheduled to take effect in April that critics have said would upend the retirement-account advisory business.

“Americans are going to have better choices and Americans are going to have better products because we’re not going to burden the banks with literally hundreds of billions of dollars of regulatory costs every year,” White House National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn said in an interview with The Wall Street Journal. “The banks are going to be able to price product more efficiently and more effectively to consumers.”

PM11:14am

No wonder the mood on Wall St is extremely bullish

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Mr. Trump will use a memorandum to ask the labor secretary to consider rescinding a rule set to go into effect in April that orders retirement advisers, overseeing about $3 trillion in assets, to act in the best interest of their clients, Mr. Cohn said in the White House interview. He said the rule limits consumer choice.

PM11:15am

You have read that twice

PM11:15am

Investment advisers acting in the best interest of the client limits consumer choice.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Mr. Cohn said the actions are intended to pave the way for additional orders that would affect the postcrisis Financial Stability Oversight Council, the mechanism for winding down a giant faltering financial company, and the way the government supervises big financial firms that aren’t traditional banks, often referred to as systemically important financial institutions.

PM11:16am

Trump has been captured by Goldman 100%

PM11:16am

And we are still in week two.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

BE11:18am

Hm. Neither do I, these being extraordinary times. But handily, this has just dropped through.

BE11:18am

11:18 am
BE11:19am

All about trading on Trump's approval rating.

BE11:19am

Yeah, really.

BE11:19am

The Big Post Election Trades: To better understand the short term performance trends seen in the aftermath of the US Presidential election, and which trades may be most sensitive to shifting winds in Washington going forward, we analyzed how a handful of major macro indicators, stock market indices, styles, themes, sectors, and industry groups have been trading relative to trends in Trump’s favorability since the election, as tracked by Real Clear Politics. US stocks have been trading closely with shifts in Trump’s favorability, as have 10 year Treasury yields, the Dollar, and crude oil. Within US equities, small caps, value, Financials, cyclicals, domestic revenue producers, and high tax payers have been particularly tied to shifts in Trump’s favorability, as has the performance of companies headquartered in states that voted for Trump.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Shift In Investor Focus Coincided With a Shift In The Public’s Perception of the New President: When Trump’s favorability initially rose after the election, equity investor optimism was driven by an intense focus on how to position for rising interest rates and improving prospects for economic/earnings growth driven by corporate tax reform, infrastructure spending, and regulatory relief. But since Trump’s favorability peaked in mid December, that optimism has been replaced by a wait and see approach among many investors, along with a healthy dose of frustration. Equity investors have been clamoring for specifics on the timing and details of Trump’s tax plans – which simply aren’t available to know just yet, and seem likely to remain unknowable for quite some time – and have been struggling to understand the implications of some of the pieces of tax reform being floated for the companies they follow (in particular, border adjustment). Meanwhile, more controversial issues with less clear implications for the broader equity market have moved into the national spotlight like health care policy, immigration and global trade policy.

BE11:20am

So .............

BE11:20am

Which US Equity Market Trades Have Been Most Closely Aligned With Trump’s Favorability?
― Size & Style: Small caps have been more positively correlated with Trump’s favorability than large. The small/large trade has also been aligned with Trump’s favorability. Within each size segment, the value indices have been more positively correlated with Trump’s favorability than the growth indices. Additionally, the value/growth trade has been positively correlated with Trump’s favorability. Beyond interest rates, these relationships may be explained by the fact that small caps and value are being treated as risk on/risk off vehicles.
― Sectors & industry Groups: Among the 11 sectors, Financials has been most positively correlated with Trump’s favorability. Among the 24 industry groups, Banks has been most positively correlated. Diversified Financials and Insurance are as well, but to a lesser degree. This is not surprising since Treasury yields are also moving in sync with Trump’s favorability. We also suspect that Financials, like small caps, have been trading on anticipation of better economic growth, and that when Trump’s favorability falls, the perception of his mandate to govern and ability to cooperate with Republicans on key agenda items also weakens. Outside of Financials, Energy also stands out as positively correlated to Trump’s favorability, not surprising given the recent link between oil prices and Trump’s favorability.
― Key Themes: When we carved up the mid and large cap universe by a handful of themes that we track (effective tax rate, international revenue exposure, cyclicals vs. defensives), we found that stocks with high tax rates, purely domestic revenue exposures, and cyclicals have been more positively correlated with Trump’s favorability than those with lower tax rates, high int’l exposure, and defensives.
― Election Results: Given the split seen in the Electoral College and popular vote, we also examined the performance of stocks since the election based on the location of the company headquarters, and whether the state cast its electoral votes for Trump or Clinton. Post election, our Trump basket has outperformed the broader market, and it has also outperformed our Clinton basket. The Trump basket’s performance vs. the broader market has also been positively correlated with Trump’s favorability. Interestingly, companies in the Trump basket have been more likely to raise guidance during the reporting season than those in the Clinton basket, a departure from trends seen throughout 2016.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

US Stocks Highly Overvalued Using Current 2018 EPS Expectations: Investors have been asking how valuations look on 2018 EPS, when it is becoming more likely (in our personal view, as opposed to 2017) that stock market friendly policy changes in Washington could materialize. On current 2018 expectations, US stocks still look highly overvalued, with FY2 P/E’s in line with past highs for both small caps and large caps. Although small caps don’t look expensive vs. large caps on our multi factor model yet, they do look pricey vs. large using FY2 P/E. Some upside to 2018 EPS expectations may eventually materialize, but until it does, it is difficult to argue against the idea that stock market valuations are highly stretched.

BE11:21am

This seems a not unreasonable view to take, if you're in charge of money.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 204.60, up 3.1 (+1.54%), High: 206.20, Low: 203.20, Volume: 6.82m
11:26 am
PM11:27am

Performance since early December been quite eye catching

BE11:27am

Lots of reasons for that, not solely the possibility of Liberty buying the lot.

BE11:27am

Though, clearly, that's a reason.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

And it's a reason talked about -- albeit somewhat circumlocutory -- by Investec this morning.

BE11:28am

We upgrade to Buy from Hold on a near-term trading basis and move to a probability-weighted PT of 228p (from 200p based on peer multiples). While we remain concerned over long-term TV prospects, near-term sentiment is unusually gloomy post a tougher FY16 and Brexit/domestic fears. These negatives look increasingly priced in, in our view, with recent better/less bad trade press comment on TV advertising. We see strategic value/M&A questions continuing given ITV’s positioning, a big US stakeholder and weak sterling.

PM11:01am

Bit surprised to be here on time.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Strategic considerations/M&A could remain a backstop, in our view, given the Liberty Global stake (9.9%), possible top management hiatus and weak sterling making UK high profile media assets attractive (Sky/Fox). Our new probability-weighted 228p SOTP PT rolls over to FY17E figures with an ongoing value at 213p (75% weighted in our PT) and a 25% weighting for a bid (30% premium) at 276p.

BE11:29am

A backstop backdrop.

BE11:29am

Also ...........

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Sentiment and forecasts turned negative last year as Net Advertising Revenue (NAR) growth reversed. We had moved to FY17/18E -5%/-1% LFL, but given better than feared UK GDP expectations and macro sentiment, we believe numbers now look cautious and we tweak our forecast to -4% LFL as of today. We will get firm Q1 outlook guidance with the FY figures on 1 March, and note that trade press reports suggest Dec/Jan TV advertising was not as bad as expected.

BE11:30am

Forecasts – we move FY17E NAR LFL to -4% (-5% before), which implies -3.6% allowing for UTV. FY16E is unchanged at -4% LFL (-2.7% including UTV) and FY18E at -1.2%. FY16E adj. EPS is unchanged at 16p, with FY17/18E increasing by +2% to 15.9p/15.5p (from 15.5p/15.2p).

BE11:30am

Valuation – shares have de-rated from the heady upgrade momentum days, with CY17E P/E at a more modest 12.7x and an adj. EV/EBITDA of 9.8x. The adj. FCF/dividend yield is 5%/4%, with FCF held back by increased drama production working capital flows (FY16/17E £80m/year) and we include deferred consideration in FCF yield. ITV is still highly cash generative with FY17E operating cashflow at £556m vs dividends at £299m, though assumed deferred consideration holds back net cash inflows to £94m vs FY17E net debt at £544m (0.6x net debt/EBITDA).

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Seems to me if Liberty is buying ITV and buying Vodafone's UK business, there's going to be rather a lot of Liberty debt out there.

PM11:32am

Ive never quite understood how Liberty just borrows and borrows and borrows

BE11:34am

Its EV/EBITDA is extraordinary. I can only guess it doesn't have covenants, like Glencore of old.

11:34 am
PM11:34am

$25bn of bonds out there

PM11:34am

BE11:35am

Anyway, Vodafone was yesterday. Let's not head back down that rabbit hole.

11:35 am
undefined
PM11:36am

It's quite, market wise

BE11:36am

(@Mr Gekko: I haven't done the work here. What's its net asset valuation and how does it get depreciated?)

11:36 am
BE11:37am

It's rubbish today. Real struggle to find anything.

BE11:37am

There's a Halma upgrade, as mentioned on the right earlier.

BE11:38am

For anyone really interested in fire alarms, here's the upshot.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Halma’s shares have pulled back 20% from their October 2016 high of 1126p, we believe driven by the rotation out of low volatility ‘bond proxy’ stocks combined with mildly disappointing interim results (despite full year expectations remaining unchanged) and an unforgiving valuation. The pullback in the shares, as well as rotation within the sector towards more cyclically exposed stocks, leaves them trading on a 12-month forward PER of 21.9x our current estimates, representing a 13% premium to the UK Capital Goods sector average, which compares with their five-year average premium of 30% and 10-year premium of 22%. This is the best sector relative value that the shares have offered for nearly two and a half years (since August 2014). We admire Halma for its consistent, long-term record and therefore view this as a good opportunity to gain exposure to it and upgrade our rating from Equal Weight to Overweight.

BE11:39am

Halma disappointed slightly with its interim results largely due a poor first contribution from its largest two recent acquisitions. This was due to delays in gaining customer approval prior to shipment of a major contract at Firetrace and subsequent shipments on one of CenTrak’s major contracts suffered postponement due to third-party delays. We view both these issues as temporary. We also believe the outlook at Process Safety (19% of group sales; 22% EBITA and 40% of sales from resources markets) should be improving.

BE11:39am

Halma’s strong consistent track record begs the question as to what the group might be producing if this can be maintained over the next five years. We model various scenarios based on ranges in the PER ascribed the shares in five years’ time. Of note is that its strong EPS growth has not been driven by significant operating margin expansion, which may indicate greater sustainability. Our model suggests that sustained CAGR in EPS of 11% (in line with the last five years), a PER of 20.3x (5yr average and lower than Halma’s current multiple), plus DPS CAGR of 5% would generate a TSR of 9%pa, rising to 11% if EPS CAGR were 13% (in line with 10yr CAGR FY05-15). Our calculations do not assume dividend reinvestment.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

No other reason I've seen for the pop.

Halma PLC (HLMA:LSE): Last: 970.00, up 44 (+4.75%), High: 996.00, Low: 944.00, Volume: 827.49k

@Blue horseshoe mentions Admiral. Nothing to add to the very vague speculation we've chucked into the market repeatedly over the past six or so weeks.

Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 1,827, up 34 (+1.90%), High: 1,829, Low: 1,782, Volume: 129.62k
BE11:42am

There was a big self-driving car insurance conference yesterday, incidentally.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

(As in, big conference. Not big cars.)

BE11:42am

(The cars are normal sized, I think.)

PM11:43am

Is it that thin? That we're going to have a fresh row about self driving cars?

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Fantasy transport

BE11:43am

We're not going to have that row. Morgan Stanley can have it for us, since they were there.

PM11:43am

MS been smoking fumes on this front for a while

11:44 am
BE11:45am

You mean their long-term stuff? I dunno. Now that the US is reverting to Wild West levels of regulation, why not let a robot drive your Chrysler mini-van?

BE11:45am

I mean, whatever right?

BE11:45am

Here's MOST.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Motor insurance is likely to shift from coverage of the driver to product liability coverage, especially as the technology shifts towards partially and fully autonomous vehicles. This is supported in the UK by the government's expected plans to retain compulsory motor insurance for autonomous vehicles in the Modern Transport Bill, due to be published soon. Motorists will likely have coverage from their insurers in the event of an accident, even if the vehicle was operating autonomously, because the coverage will be extended to product liability. Where the vehicle is at fault, the insurer will then be able to seek compensation from the manufacturer.

BE11:45am

Concerns were expressed over the risks of intermediate technologies, as drivers may not always be aware that they need to be ready to take over from the vehicle at any moment. Some manufacturers, concerned with the risks, have decided to skip the intermediate stages entirely. In jurisdictions where the law is not clear, insurers may find determining liability for accidents difficult.

BE11:45am

Sounds a good day out.

11:45 am
PM11:45am

Ok, i can see this argument over shifting to product liability

BE11:46am

There is still a lot of uncertainty over who will have access to connected car data. This is especially pertinent for insurers who will need at least a basic level of data in order to determine liability in the event of an accident.

For motor insurers globally, all this means that adaptation is crucial to ensure future competitiveness. In the short term we would expect increased technology in cars to reduce the frequency of claims for insurers, possibly leading to higher profits. However, 5-10 years out, we think insurers may need to find new pools of risk, or expand to become service providers for motorists.

BE11:46am

They're neutral on Admiral. Scan back old sessions for the reasons why.

11:46 am
undefined
BE11:47am

Beazley too, since we're on insurance.

Beazley PLC (BEZ:LSE): Last: 444.00, up 35.3 (+8.64%), High: 450.20, Low: 432.00, Volume: 4.11m
11:47 am
BE11:47am

10p special.

BE11:48am

And the FY shows 18% ROE, which is a beat.

BE11:48am

PBT at $293m versus $260m consensus. Underwriting and investment portfolio doing okay.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Consensus expected a special div, though was only at 7.4p

BE11:49am

Outlook positive. Demand for specialist stuff to SMEs strong.

BE11:50am

Caz is pleased.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Increasing estimates. We increase our PBT estimates by 4%/3% for FY17E/18E mainly reflecting improved growth assumptions. As a result our warranted P/B derived Dec-17 TP increases to 470p (was 460p).

BE11:50am

UBS slightly less pleased.

BE11:51am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?

A: We highlight 1) Special dividend of 10p was ahead of both consensus and UBSe. We had seen some risk to market expectations here given increasing capital requirements to fund growth (required capital increased +11% c$1.5bn in FY16). Looking out from here, we expect continued growth in capital requirements to limit scope for specials, should losses run in-line with expectations. 2) 2H16 GWP growth of +9% (1H16: +2.2%) driven by growth in specialty of +12% (1H16: +17%) and a more stable premium base in more challenged lines such as property, marine and reinsurance (and in fact growth in some of these lines). 3) Rates across the book declined by 2% at FY16, in-line with the trends reported at 1H16 and FY15. Rates are still increasing by 1% in specialty (again in-line with 1H16) which lends resilience to the book.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Q: How would we expect investors to react?

A: Shares have outperformed Eurostoxx by 4% YTD and valuation is back at 1.7xTNAV for a 14% normalised RoTNAV. Despite still elevated valuation, these results look supportive.

BE11:51am

RBC's pleased.

BE11:51am

Despite Beazley trading at a premium to the Lloyd's sector (1.8x 2016 book value vs peer average pf 1.4x)., we believe that these results highlight why the company deserves its rating; strong growth in niche areas, strong ROEs, and a well capitalised balance sheet should all offer attractions to investors in our view.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Shore's pleased.

BE11:52am

The other feature of the statement which we believe is worth highlighting is its tone. This is a company operating in rating environments which remain under considerable pressure. However, through a programme of diversification by product, such as cyber, and territory, such as the US and Singapore, together with strict pricing discipline Beazley is carving out niche pockets of profitable growth. This is combined with a clear focus on delivering value for shareholders, as evidenced by another special dividend, despite the increased capital requirements emanating from the growth in the specialty book. Beazley continues to go from strength to strength.

BE11:52am

There is no talk of M&A in today’s statement and, indeed, we do not believe Beazley is particularly vulnerable. However, the underwriting delivery, the capital discipline together with the significant diversification benefits its specialty book would offer a potential predator should not be overlooked.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Peel Hunt .... not pleased!

BE11:52am

Beazley reported a better than expected set of full year 2016
figures largely thanks to higher than expected reserve releases.
Stripping out reserve releases underwriting results were broadly
in line. Capital requirements are increasing on the back of the
Company’s growth strategy and a decline in diversification
benefits, putting pressure on the Company to retain earnings and
reduce dividend payments. In order to maintain a stable solvency
ratio (136%) we believe the scope for special dividends will be
further eroded this year. Hence, we maintain our Reduce stance
as yield support wanes and a premium multiple of 1.8x TNAV
persists.

BE11:53am

There. That's more coverage of Beazley than I think any mainstream news organisation has offered before, or will again.

11:53 am

Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 316.60, up 2.6 (+0.83%), High: 318.40, Low: 315.20, Volume: 61.60k
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Anyway, every time I ask Feltcollaredsourcees familiar with Mediclinic they point me to the November statement that it's fine to stick at 29.9% and is focused on consolidating existing ops.

BE12:00pm

I've not asked for a while though. So ........ who knows. Is it midday yet?

undefined
